messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] re: censorship (tampons)

>
>
>I broke mine taking a tampon out. God, did that hurt. It was a relief,
>though, since it made tampon use a lot easier afterward.

Guessing it made your first sexual experience more pleasant as well.
Tia

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] re: censorship (tampons)
messages.msgSnippet: ... I broke mine taking a tampon out.  God, did that hurt.  It was a relief, though, since it made tampon use a lot easier afterward. Nancy  (Boldly Going
messages.messageBody:
on 1/20/04 1:43 PM, Tia Leschke at leschke@... wrote:

>
>>
>> I don't know, honestly. That wasn't the concern she expressed to me, it was
>> that she feels tampons are for sexually active women and that young girls
>> should definitely not be thinking about putting anything into their
>> vaginas. She
>> planned to tell her daughter that tampons are for adults period - hence
>> the need
>> for a book that doesn't mention tampon use for teens.
>
> My only guess here is that she's concerned about her daughter's hymen. She
> might want to know that those get broken other ways, and almost never get
> broken inserting a tampon. That's *if* it's an issue. It wouldn't be with me.
> Tia
>

I broke mine taking a tampon out. God, did that hurt. It was a relief,
though, since it made tampon use a lot easier afterward.

Nancy (Boldly Going Where No List Has Gone Before)

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] re: censorship (tampons)
messages.msgSnippet: ... My only guess here is that she s concerned about her daughter s hymen. She might want to know that those get broken other ways, and almost never get broken
messages.messageBody:
>
>I don't know, honestly. That wasn't the concern she expressed to me, it was
>that she feels tampons are for sexually active women and that young girls
>should definitely not be thinking about putting anything into their
>vaginas. She
>planned to tell her daughter that tampons are for adults period - hence
>the need
>for a book that doesn't mention tampon use for teens.

My only guess here is that she's concerned about her daughter's hymen. She
might want to know that those get broken other ways, and almost never get
broken inserting a tampon. That's *if* it's an issue. It wouldn't be with me.
Tia

messages.subject: re: censorship (tampons)
messages.msgSnippet: ** So she s probably going to make her daughter use cloth pads. What a way to turn her against them for life. Yes, there are some problems with tampons,
messages.messageBody:
** So she's probably going to make her daughter use cloth pads. What a way to
turn her against them for life. Yes, there are some problems with tampons,
particularly the bleached ones. If I were just starting out rather than
essentially finished, I would be looking at alternatives.**

I don't know, honestly. That wasn't the concern she expressed to me, it was
that she feels tampons are for sexually active women and that young girls
should definitely not be thinking about putting anything into their vaginas. She
planned to tell her daughter that tampons are for adults period - hence the need
for a book that doesn't mention tampon use for teens.

Deborah


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
